content.title: Lower Gastrointestinal Bleeding
content.summary: Bleeding from the GI tract distal to the ligament of Treitz presenting primarily with hematochezia, most commonly from diverticulosis, with colonoscopy as the diagnostic modality of choice
key_points: Bleeding distal to ligament of Treitz: small bowel, colon, rectum, anus
Diverticulosis is most common cause (30-40%); bleeding is usually painless and self-limited
Hematochezia (bright red blood per rectum) is typical; melena suggests slower upper or proximal source
Rule out upper GI source if hemodynamically unstable (15% of brisk UGIB presents as hematochezia)
Colonoscopy is diagnostic modality of choice; timing depends on severity
Most LGIB (80-85%) stops spontaneously; supportive care often sufficient
Angiography with embolization for ongoing bleeding if colonoscopy cannot localize
content.statement: Lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB) is hemorrhage from the GI tract distal to the ligament of Treitz, typically presenting with hematochezia, requiring systematic evaluation to identify the source and determine appropriate intervention.

explanation.intuition: When blood appears fresh and red in the stool, it's usually from somewhere close to the exit - the colon, rectum, or anus. The most common culprits are outpouchings of the colon wall (diverticula) that erode into arteries, or abnormal blood vessels (angiodysplasia) that bleed.
explanation.key_insight: The key challenge in LGIB is that most bleeding stops spontaneously, making it harder to localize the source. However, when bleeding is brisk, always rule out an upper GI source first (even hematochezia can be from massive UGIB). Colonoscopy after prep is best for stable patients; angiography for active, ongoing bleeding.
explanation.technical_details: LGIB pathophysiology varies: Diverticula form at sites of vasa recta penetration (weakest point), and arterial bleeding occurs from erosion at the dome or neck. Angiodysplasia are ectatic, tortuous blood vessels in the mucosa/submucosa, often in the right colon. Ischemic colitis causes watershed mucosal injury at the splenic flexure. Hemorrhoids cause painless, bright red bleeding separate from stool.

definitions_glossary.lower_gi_bleeding: Bleeding from GI tract distal to ligament of Treitz (small bowel, colon, rectum)
definitions_glossary.hematochezia: Passage of fresh, red blood per rectum; typical of LGIB
definitions_glossary.diverticulosis: Presence of colonic diverticula; most common cause of LGIB
definitions_glossary.angiodysplasia: Ectatic blood vessels in bowel wall; second most common cause in elderly
definitions_glossary.ligament_of_treitz: Anatomic landmark at duodenojejunal junction; divides upper from lower GI
definitions_glossary.colonoscopy: Endoscopic examination of colon; diagnostic modality of choice for LGIB
definitions_glossary.angiography: Catheter-based imaging of mesenteric arteries; can localize and treat active bleeding
definitions_glossary.embolization: Catheter-based delivery of material to occlude bleeding vessel
definitions_glossary.tagged_rbc_scan: Nuclear medicine study detecting slow bleeding (0.1 mL/min); localizes general area
definitions_glossary.obscure_gi_bleeding: Bleeding from GI tract with negative upper and lower endoscopy
definitions_glossary.ischemic_colitis: Watershed mucosal injury from reduced colonic blood flow; typically left colon
definitions_glossary.hemorrhoids: Vascular cushions in anal canal; cause painless, bright red bleeding

pathophysiology.mechanism: Vascular injury, mucosal erosion, or structural abnormalities causing hemorrhage into the colonic or rectal lumen

anorectal: Hemorrhoids (most common cause of minor bleeding)

risk_factors: History of colorectal polyps or cancer

clinical_presentation: Hematochezia (bright red blood per rectum) - typical
Signs of hypovolemia if significant blood loss
Abdominal pain suggests ischemia, IBD, or infectious cause

initial_assessment.rule_out_ugib: If hemodynamically unstable, brisk bleeding, or BUN:Cr >30, consider UGIB
initial_assessment.digital_rectal_exam: Assess for hemorrhoids, masses, blood character

resuscitation.transfusion: Restrictive threshold (Hgb <7 g/dL) if stable; liberal if ischemia/active CAD

colonoscopy.timing: Within 24h for most; urgent if hemodynamically unstable after resuscitation
colonoscopy.preparation: Rapid bowel prep (4-6L PEG solution over 3-4 hours) improves diagnostic yield
colonoscopy.therapeutic_options: Epinephrine injection, thermal coagulation, clips, band ligation

if_colonoscopy_non_diagnostic: Tagged RBC scan (detects ≥0.1 mL/min; localizes general area)
diagnostic_approach.egd: Consider if hemodynamically unstable or high suspicion for UGIB
diagnostic_approach.capsule_endoscopy_enteroscopy: For suspected small bowel source after negative colonoscopy and EGD

therapeutic_interventions.endoscopic: Clips, thermal coagulation, epinephrine injection for localized lesions
therapeutic_interventions.angiographic_embolization: For ongoing bleeding not amenable to endoscopic therapy
therapeutic_interventions.surgery: Segmental resection if source localized; subtotal colectomy if unlocalized and ongoing massive bleeding

supportive_care: Hold anticoagulants (coordinate with cardiology if indicated)
Resume anticoagulation once bleeding controlled based on indication

skos.definition: Bleeding from the GI tract distal to the ligament of Treitz presenting with hematochezia or maroon stools

subcodes: K62.5 - Hemorrhage of anus and rectum
K57.31 - Diverticulosis of large intestine with bleeding

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features differentiating LGIB from UGIB
Identify common causes of LGIB by age and presentation
Apply diagnostic algorithm for LGIB evaluation
Determine appropriate timing and preparation for colonoscopy
Know when to use CT angiography, conventional angiography, or surgery
Manage anticoagulation in the setting of LGIB
clinical_pearls: Rule out UGIB first in hemodynamically unstable patients with hematochezia (15% is brisk UGIB)
Diverticular bleeding is painless and typically from right colon; usually self-limited
Most LGIB (80-85%) stops spontaneously - colonoscopy is often diagnostic, not therapeutic
Bowel prep before colonoscopy improves diagnostic yield significantly
Angiodysplasia most common in right colon; associated with aortic stenosis, CKD
Ischemic colitis presents with abdominal pain before bleeding - unlike diverticular/angiodysplasia
CT angiography can localize active bleeding and guide subsequent intervention
Tagged RBC scan is sensitive for slow bleeding but localizes only to region, not specific source

common_questions: Painless hematochezia in elderly - most likely cause?
Hemodynamically unstable with hematochezia - first step?
When is surgery indicated for LGIB?
